articles.headline: How Lucrative Thy Branches
articles.snippet: Christmas trees are a small but highly profitable part of the timber industry, where profit can be decades in coming.
articles.abstract: Christmas trees are a small but highly profitable part of the timber industry, where profit can be decades in coming.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chris Botek, a tree grower in Lehighton, Pa., is used to people being shocked by how much his Christmas trees cost.

articles.headline: Studios Unfazed by Colossal Wrecks
articles.snippet: The blockbuster model, despite a surplus of coming titles and a frightful recent track record, remains a profitable model for the biggest filmmakers.
articles.abstract: The blockbuster model, despite a surplus of coming titles and a frightful recent track record, remains a profitable model for the biggest filmmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Hollywood film studios, 2013 is shaping up as “the year of the flop,” as the public radio host Brian Lehrer described it on the air in August.

articles.headline: Weighing Health Plans: The Devilish Details
articles.snippet: As a deadline approaches, more people are trying to figure out the intricate cost-sharing arrangements of various options.
articles.abstract: As a deadline approaches, more people are trying to figure out the intricate cost-sharing arrangements of various options.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the way home from a bar in the wee hours of the morning, Branden Eastwood, 29, managed to break his ankle stepping into a cab. He wasn’t insured, so it became an expensive night out: He received $42,000 in medical bills from a Georgetown hospital.

articles.headline: Yemen Deaths Test Claims of New Drone Policy
articles.snippet: The reported deaths of innocent people in a wedding procession this month illuminated the reality behind the Obama administration’s new drone policy.
articles.abstract: The reported deaths of innocent people in a wedding procession this month illuminated the reality behind the Obama administration’s new drone policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In some respects, the drone strike in Yemen last week resembled so many others from recent years: A hail of missiles slammed into a convoy of trucks on a remote desert road, killing at least 12 people.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: In Apology, and a Sale, Target Tries to Appease
articles.snippet: Scrambling to tamp down consumer outrage over the theft of credit and debit card data, Target announced it would offer a 10 percent discount at its stores this weekend.
articles.abstract: Scrambling to tamp down consumer outrage over the theft of credit and debit card data, Target announced it would offer a 10 percent discount at its stores this weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scrambling to tamp down consumer outrage over the theft of credit and debit card data from more than 40 million of its customers, Target announced on Friday that it would offer a 10 percent discount on purchases inside its stores on Saturday and Sunday — the final shopping weekend of the holiday season.

articles.headline: Libya Militias Fleeing Cities, Leaving Chaos
articles.snippet: Civilian protesters and armed groups have chased militias from Tripoli and Benghazi for the first time since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011.
articles.abstract: Civilian protesters and armed groups have chased militias from Tripoli and Benghazi for the first time since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — For the first time since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011, the independent militias that dominated Libya’s biggest cities and sometimes cowed the central government have fled from the streets, chased away by a combination of civilian protesters and armed groups.

articles.headline: New Health Law Frustrates Many in Middle Class
articles.snippet: While the Affordable Care Act clearly benefits those at the low and high ends of the income scale, many middle-class Americans don’t qualify for health care subsidies, and are facing steep premium prices.
articles.abstract: While the Affordable Care Act clearly benefits those at the low and high ends of the income scale, many middle-class Americans don’t qualify for health care subsidies, and are facing steep premium prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ginger Chapman and her husband, Doug, are sitting on the health care cliff.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas, Reed Abelson and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: Setting the Table for a Regal Butterfly Comeback, With Milkweed
articles.snippet: Conservationists have planted milkweed, a favored food of the butterfly, along migratory routes where natural habitat has been plowed under for crops.
articles.abstract: Conservationists have planted milkweed, a favored food of the butterfly, along migratory routes where natural habitat has been plowed under for crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa — Bounding out of a silver Ford pickup into the single-digit wind-flogged flatness that is Iowa in December, Laura Jackson strode to a thicket of desiccated sticks and plucked a paisley-shaped prize.

articles.headline: Off Limits, but Blessed by the Fed
articles.snippet: Documents show how the Fed gave JPMorgan Chase a free hand to expand in businesses like electricity that are typically off limits to big banks.
articles.abstract: Documents show how the Fed gave JPMorgan Chase a free hand to expand in businesses like electricity that are typically off limits to big banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The good news arrived in a confidential letter from the Federal Reserve Board in Washington. The nation’s biggest bank, JPMorgan Chase, had won the right to expand its reach in a lucrative business that has nothing to do with banking: electricity.

articles.headline: Now Taking World Cup Bookings, Rio’s Slums
articles.snippet: With hotel rooms in short supply, the residents of Rio de Janeiro’s favelas, or slums, are renting out their homes to visiting soccer fans from around the globe.
articles.abstract: With hotel rooms in short supply, the residents of Rio de Janeiro’s favelas, or slums, are renting out their homes to visiting soccer fans from around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Gun battles still boom through the streets. Drug dealers still ply their trade in the labyrinth of alleyways. Residents of the Rocinha neighborhood still fume over the brutal tactics of the police, who were recently charged with torturing and killing an impoverished bricklayer.

articles.headline: Master of His Virtual Domain
articles.snippet: George Yao, an ordinary guy, spent $250 a week conquering the online game Clash of Clans, at one point bringing five iPads into the shower with him so that none of his accounts would go inactive.
articles.abstract: George Yao, an ordinary guy, spent $250 a week conquering the online game Clash of Clans, at one point bringing five iPads into the shower with him so that none of his accounts would go inactive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, a few months before his eighth birthday, my son announced that he wanted to join a clan.

articles.headline: Into the Bitcoin Mines
articles.snippet: In a bunker in Iceland, powerful computers are whirring 24 hours a day — and extracting an invisible currency.
articles.abstract: In a bunker in Iceland, powerful computers are whirring 24 hours a day — and extracting an invisible currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the flat lava plain of Reykjanesbaer, Iceland, near the Arctic Circle, you can find the mines of Bitcoin.

articles.headline: When the Right to Bear Arms Includes the Mentally Ill
articles.snippet: Law enforcement is often powerless when it comes to keeping firearms out of the hands of people who are mentally ill, an unresolved issue in the debate over the Second Amendment.
articles.abstract: Law enforcement is often powerless when it comes to keeping firearms out of the hands of people who are mentally ill, an unresolved issue in the debate over the Second Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last April, workers at Middlesex Hospital in Connecticut called the police to report that a psychiatric patient named Mark Russo had threatened to shoot his mother if officers tried to take the 18 rifles and shotguns he kept at her house. Mr. Russo, who was off his medication for paranoid schizophrenia, also talked about the recent elementary school massacre in Newtown and told a nurse that he “could take a chair and kill you or bash your head in between the eyes,” court records show.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Is Arkansas Still Friendly to Bill? Clinton Tests It
articles.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton, who has always nurtured his ties with his home state, is diving into the 2014 campaign in support of former aides and protégés, testing how much Arkansas still loves him.
articles.abstract: Former President Bill Clinton, who has always nurtured his ties with his home state, is diving into the 2014 campaign in support of former aides and protégés, testing how much Arkansas still loves him.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — When it came time to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the opening of a dam on the Little Red River this fall, former President Bill Clinton came running. But once he arrived in the state, he had more on his mind than just public works.

articles.headline: Free to Speak About Russia, but Now From a Safe Distance
articles.snippet: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former billionaire and a critic of President Vladimir V. Putin’s who was imprisoned for a decade, said in Berlin that he would work to help other political prisoners.
articles.abstract: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former billionaire and a critic of President Vladimir V. Putin’s who was imprisoned for a decade, said in Berlin that he would work to help other political prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After a decade of incarceration that transformed him from Russia’s wealthiest man into its most famous political prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky faced journalists in Berlin on Sunday following a head-spinning 36-hour journey to freedom.

articles.headline: China Deal Gives Apple Big Market to Court
articles.snippet: The agreement to bring the iPhone to China Mobile could, at least initially, give Apple a big lift into the vast Chinese market, analysts say, increasing its global sales.
articles.abstract: The agreement to bring the iPhone to China Mobile could, at least initially, give Apple a big lift into the vast Chinese market, analysts say, increasing its global sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just about any way you slice it, 763 million customers is a huge potential pie.
articles.byline: By Eric Pfanner and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Strong Profit Margin at Paramount Pictures Underlines a Hollywood Shift
articles.snippet: Brad Grey of Paramount Pictures has chosen to produce fewer films, giving up revenue, but increasing profitability as the industry moves into survival mode.
articles.abstract: Brad Grey of Paramount Pictures has chosen to produce fewer films, giving up revenue, but increasing profitability as the industry moves into survival mode.
articles.lead_paragraph: The weather wobbled between snow and rain, with ankle-deep slush in gridlocked streets. But Brad Grey, the chief executive of Paramount Pictures, refused to fret about whether the mess would keep the Manhattan elite away from a gala premiere of Martin Scorsese’s “The Wolf of Wall Street” last Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: In Tech Buying, U.S. Still Stuck in Last Century
articles.snippet: Despite the furor over the rollout of HealthCare.gov, there is little evidence that the Obama administration is moving quickly to change how the government hires and manages private technology companies.
articles.abstract: Despite the furor over the rollout of HealthCare.gov, there is little evidence that the Obama administration is moving quickly to change how the government hires and manages private technology companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four years after President Obama vowed to “dramatically reform the way we do business on contracts,” the spectacular failure of the HealthCare.gov website has renewed calls for changes in how the government hires and manages private technology companies.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: Amid Steady Deportation, Fear and Worry Multiply Among Immigrants
articles.snippet: Immigrant leaders see a broad community impact as deportations separate parents from children and undocumented immigrants from those here legally.
articles.abstract: Immigrant leaders see a broad community impact as deportations separate parents from children and undocumented immigrants from those here legally.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Karen Sandoval’s promising life in this city fell apart in one day last summer when she went to buy school supplies for her two daughters.

articles.headline: Investment Strategy Rises From Obscurity
articles.snippet: Since the financial crisis, the popularity of a securities structure, the master limited partnership, has soared, and it is outperforming the broader stock market.
articles.abstract: Since the financial crisis, the popularity of a securities structure, the master limited partnership, has soared, and it is outperforming the broader stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the billionaire Carl C. Icahn took control of CVR Energy last year, critics thought the dog had finally caught the car.

articles.headline: When ‘60 Minutes’ Checks Its Journalistic Skepticism at the Door
articles.snippet: Viewers expect and deserve the show to bring its A game when it takes on a huge issue like the N.S.A., to serve as a stand-in for the American people and ask the uncomfortable questions.
articles.abstract: Viewers expect and deserve the show to bring its A game when it takes on a huge issue like the N.S.A., to serve as a stand-in for the American people and ask the uncomfortable questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, a study commissioned by the president concluded that the National Security Agency had reached too far into the private lives of Americans. The study, which came after a series of journalistic revelations exposing the agency’s surveillance practices, recommended numerous reforms that would curb the N.S.A.’s prerogatives. President Obama said he was “open to many” of the suggestions.

articles.headline: A Snowier Silicon Valley in BlackBerry’s Backyard
articles.snippet: The Waterloo area in Ontario remains a magnet for the high-tech industry, despite the misfortunes of its best-known success story.
articles.abstract: The Waterloo area in Ontario remains a magnet for the high-tech industry, despite the misfortunes of its best-known success story.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Ontario — BlackBerry is down, but its hometown is far from out.

articles.headline: On Jammed Jets, Sardines Turn on One Another
articles.snippet: Airlines are shrinking the size of their seats, raising revenue but also tensions between frustrated passengers.
articles.abstract: Airlines are shrinking the size of their seats, raising revenue but also tensions between frustrated passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Flying coach can be a bruising experience these days.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Martha C. White

articles.headline: U.S. Flouts Its Own Advice in Procuring Overseas Clothing
articles.snippet: Despite a policy against using plants that breach safety laws, the United States government spends more than $1.5 billion a year at overseas factories with a pattern of violations.
articles.abstract: Despite a policy against using plants that breach safety laws, the United States government spends more than $1.5 billion a year at overseas factories with a pattern of violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the world’s biggest clothing buyers, the United States government spends more than $1.5 billion a year at factories overseas, acquiring everything from the royal blue shirts worn by airport security workers to the olive button-downs required for forest rangers and the camouflage pants sold to troops on military bases.

articles.headline: Korea Execution Is Tied to Clash Over Businesses
articles.snippet: The execution of the uncle of Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, is said to have had its roots in a firefight over who would profit from the country’s most lucrative exports: coal, clams and crabs.
articles.abstract: The execution of the uncle of Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, is said to have had its roots in a firefight over who would profit from the country’s most lucrative exports: coal, clams and crabs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The execution of the uncle of Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, had its roots in a firefight between forces loyal to Mr. Kim and those supporting the man who was supposed to be his regent, according to accounts that are being pieced together by South Korean and American officials. The clash was over who would profit from North Korea’s most lucrative exports: coal, clams and crabs.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger
